Award.AwardTitle: Texas Analysis and Mathematical Physics Symposium
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding for US participation for the conference "Texas Analysis and Mathematical Physics Symposium (TexAMP)", which will be held at Baylor University in Waco, TX on Octobert 26-28, 2018. This will be the 6th annual TexAMP meeting, and will feature talks by eight prominent researchers in the fields of mathematical physics, with specialties in spectral theory, geometric analysis, harmonic analysis, integrable systems, random matrix theory, asymptotic analysis, partial differential equations, geometric measure theory, functional analysis, microlocal analysis, scattering theory, and semiclassical methods.

The conference focuses on recent developments in Analysis, especially in the field of mathematical physics. A number of distinguished mathematicians have agreed to attend and speak at this conference series. This award gives early career researchers, members of underrepresented groups, researchers not funded by NSF and the like an opportunity to attend and participate in this conference. The organizing committee will strive to make this funding opportunity known to target groups through a number of different activities. More information will be made available at the conference webpage: https://sites.google.com/site/texamp2018/home.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Texas Analysis and Mathematical Physics Symposium 2018 was the sixth conference in the series dedicated to intersecting areas of Mathematical Physics, Analysis and PDE's..  It took place from 26-28 October 2018, at Baylor University.

Invited talks were presented by Yaiza Canzani (University of North Carolina; Understanding the growth of Laplace eigenfunctions), Nets Katz (Caltech; An explicit exponent in the discretized sum product theorem), Peter Miller (University of Michigan; Some interesting solutions of the Painleve-III equation), Marius Mitrea (University of Missouri; Fatou theorems for elliptic systems in uniformly rectifiable domains), Stefanie Petermichl (University of Toulouse; Sparse domination and dimensionless estimates for the Riesz vector), Sergei Treil (Brown University; Finite rank perturbations, matrix weights and the Aronszajn-Donoghue theory), Dan-Virgil Voiculescu (University of California Berkeley; Invariance of absolutely continuous spectra under hybrid normed ideal perturbations) and Steve Zelditch (Northwestern University; A Gutzwiller trace formula for stationary spacetimes).  

There were contributed talks by: Gokalp Alpan, Ioakeim Ampatzoglou, Niles Armstrong, Matt Blair, David Blecher, Ryan Denliger, Vladimir Dragovic, Katie Elliott, Matthew Fleeman, Rohan Ghanta, Jameson Graber, Curtis Graham, Fazel Hadadifard, Abey Lopez-Garcia, Isaac Michael, Katrina Morgan, Iurii Posukhovskyi, Alexander Reznikov, Selim Sukhtaiev, Erica Swindle, Oleksandr Vlasiuk, Zhenhua Wang, Tracy Weyand, and Aaron Yeager. 

Further details are available on the conference website, sites.google.com/site/texamp2018/.
